awd_titl_txt: Probing the Metal-Carbon Bond: High Resolution Spectroscopy of Grignard Reagents and 3d Metal Carbon Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structures, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A Program, Professor Lucy M. Ziurys of the University of Arizona is exploring the chemical structure and behavior of small, novel compounds that contain metal-carbon bonds. Of particular interest are the so-called transition metal elements like iron (Fe), copper (Cu), cobalt (Co) and titanium (Ti). Understanding how metal elements interact and bond with carbon is pivotal to the advance of many other areas of chemistry and technology, including organic and inorganic chemical synthesis, catalysis, materials science, biochemistry, and even astrochemistry. Using a microwave spectroscopy technique, Prof. Ziurys is studying the arrangement of atoms and electrons in these model molecules. The information obtained then provides important insights into larger, more complex molecules and in developing theoretical predictions. The research involves a collaborative team of experimentalists and theorists, with an emphasis on both graduate and undergraduate education. 

Professor Ziurys is studying the geometric and electronic properties of metal-bearing molecules using high-resolution, gas-phase rotational spectroscopy techniques.  The novel species being studied are small, metal carbon clusters related to metallocarbohedrenes and endohedral metallofullerenes, and classic Grignard-type reagents. They are produced by gas-phase synthetic methods utilizing Broida ovens, organometallic precursors, and laser ablation. In addition, a new spectrometer is being built to further these studies. A program has been established for undergraduate students from other, non-PhD granting institutions to participate in this research project. The broader impacts of this work include the development of millimeter/sub-millimeter experimental methodologies that are applicable to analytical chemistry and the detection of trace species in chemical mixtures.  Additionally, this research is providing student training in precision measurements and experimental techniques, theory, and synthesis involving metals, all of which are skill sets relevant to the chemical, catalysis, mining, medical, and semiconductor industries.

por.por_cntn:
Chemical reactivity in a given molecule is known to be a function of its geometric structure and the arrangement of its electrons. Over the past 50 years, it has been shown that organic molecules containing the transition metals are particularly useful in reactions that create new chemical compounds for other applications such as in pharmaceuticals and in new materials. However, in many cases, the geometric and electronic structures of such molecules are not known, as they are used in solution with many other reagents. The purpose of this project was to measure the structures of simple, model molecules representative of well-known compounds used in organic synthesis and in materials with high accuracy and fidelity, using techniques of gas-phase rotational spectroscopy. Such fundamental data, when globally assembled, provide insight into more complex systems used in chemistry. The instruments used for the measurements are not commercially available, and were designed and built by PhD students and post-doctoral scientists, and operate in the microwave and millimeter-wave regions of the electromagnetic spectrum. These instruments are used to measure the transitions between energy levels caused by a molecule's  free rotation in the gas phase, from which a molecular structure can be obtained . Also, creating these types of molecules in the gas phase required unusual chemical techniques involving electrical discharges and ablation of metal surfaces with lasers.  One class of molecules studied were simple analogs of famous Grignard-type reagents, which have long played a key role in organic chemistry and the formation of bonds between carbon atoms. Despite their importance in synthesis, not much is known about the structure of such species, except through the limited use of X-rays. One outcome of this project was the measurement of the structure of ClZnCH3  - a model molecule for a zinc-type Grignard reagent- This molecule was made by zinc naturally inserting itself between the C and Cl atoms, interesting in itself..Part of the structure determination involved measurements of isotopically-substituted species 37ClZnCH3, ClZnCD3, and ClZn13CH3, The resulting three-fold geometry is shown in the ball-and-stick figure. The most interesting result is the Cl-Zn bond length, which is ~ 0.2-0.25 angstroms shorter than those from the X-ray crystal structures. Another important outcome is the measurement the structure of the simplest form of a carbon cluster with a metal atom attached, namely ScC2. This work is the first MC2 species to be studied by any spectroscopic method, where M is a transition metal. The molecule, which has an unpaired electron and is highly reactive, was found to have a T-shaped geometry with a C-M-C angle near 36 degrees. In addition, spectra of both Sc13CC and Sc13C2 were recorded. Both the scandium and 13C nuclei have intrinsic quantum mechanical spins. The intrinsic complexity in spectra of molecules with two nuclear spins has made this project difficult. A ball-and-stick structure of ScC2 is shown in a figure.

This work was part of the doctoral theses of two graduate students. It also contributed to the education activities of other graduate and undergraduate students, including the development of scientific instruments.
